description.text: These are drop in replacement tiles for the famous scrabble game by Parker Brothers.  What these tiles provide is a hexadecimal set of characters, with point values corresponding to their numeric values.  This should provide for truly universal language support in scrabble.  Any player can feel free to deploy their words now as they would in any other version of scrabble, only now they have their choice of encoding types.  Including full unicode support!

I cut these on 5mm wood on an epilog mini.
I'd use the cdr.

description.text:
This design is a simple tool box designed specifically for the Mendel90 kit. The tool box sits at the front-left of the gantry and is secured by the existing M4 screw that also secures the base feet.  
The design incorporates two pockets, one for a set of tweezers and the other is designed to nicely hold AdanA's EZ-Snap Razor Blade Handle that can be found on Thingiverse. The rest of the compartment can be used for holding filament samples, small flashlights, and other small tools.  
This design stays clear of the moving heatbed and all other obstacles in its vicinity. Also, the box takes into account the Dibond's round corner nicely (if pairing this with Nophead's kit).

This is a remix /Meshmixer of two uploads.

Run FT-5_Z-Bed_Gap.gcode from an SDCARD after you have preheated your bed an nozzle in order to set your gap. What I normally do is run FT-5_Z-Bed_Gap.gcode and put a piece of paper under the nozzle and let it set for 15 minutes after the first iteration.

After 15 minutes pull the SDCARD out and reinsert it to stop the print. Then run it again to set the gap. I do this before every print to get best results. My gap is normally set once I can get the paper to slide between the nozzle and the bed with just a little drag.

BLTouch:
You will need two m3 screws long enough to reach bottom. The holes should be tapped so you can secure the BLTouch in fixture. As you can notice from the pictures there is not enough room for nuts at the bottom. Using an m3 screw the length of the fixture should be sufficient to hold it in place. When you tighten down the screw only tighten it a little bit after you make contact with the BLTouch as not to strip the plastic. I printed the part with 100% infill and I recommend you do as well.

A compact, adjustable Raspberry Pi camera mount that attaches to the arms on a Z-brace mod. Prints easily without supports and holds securely. Besides the peg the parts are otherwise symmetrical so you can mirror them in your slicer if you want the camera to face the other direction.

There is a small support piece underneath the peg that can be removed easily after printing. Sometimes it comes off when you remove the parts from the bed but other times it's a bit more stubborn. I find the easiest and cleanest way to remove it is to set the body piece on a table with the peg facing upwards, position a razor blade in the gap between the two parts, and tap on the top of the blade lightly with some other object. The support piece should pop off, no problem.

comments.text: How does this one work for you? It worked for me, and the prints came out fine. I made this one because I liked the funnel end. However, I felt that this one creates a lot of friction. It scrapes loudly. The bend is too fast and creates a kink for the filament. Perhaps with a curve that doesn't quite reach 90 degrees will do the trick. I may or may not remix this within the next few months, but if I do I will attribute.
comments.author: NPG3D

comments.text: I total agree as well. Originally I really liked the whole idea and look but in practice the 90 degree turn is to much for stiff PLA filament. Increasing the friction exponentially which is obviously defeating the whole purpose of smooth filament flow. I went back to the non-coned version.
comments.author: NPG3D

description.text:
tl;dr You will need to print 1 spinner body and 2 of either no_spacer_end_cap.stl, push_end_cap.stl, or spacer_end_cap.stl.
The file not_good_caps.stl is just a center bearing thumb cap, which is not bad for the short models and better_center_bearing_thumb_cap.stl would be better for the not short models.

Here are the ProtoSpinners. This is the first thing I have ever built using 3D CAD software.
So please be gentle with me...

The idea was that not all people have hands large enough to make use of the end bearing on other 3 bearing models. So, I wanted to give them to have more of a reason than just weight. On the ProtoSpinners your thumb has access to the end of the bearings and you can roll it with your thumb or on the table or your pants. Just thought it may be cool and wanted to see if I could make it work.

The first one I made was the V1.11. Then I wanted to see if people would like a shorter center bearing body version of the V1.11, thus the ProtoShort was born.

Last but not least, the ProtoFreak is just that, a freak. When I was trying to fix an uneven area at center of the spinner body, I deleted a plane and the weird blade shape just happened... so, I kept it.

Oh, and don't worry about my name being on there. You can barely see it when it is printed and the bearing covers it... I just couldn't help myself.

If anyone has ideas on ways to make it better please let me know.
And if anyone wants, I can upload the files without the supports if you think that your slicers can do better.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20% to 30% (All of mine are 30%)

Notes:

I have tried printing all of this at .2 30% with no raft and no support (except for the built in ones) and it has worked. I will say that some of the little end caps may have issues with adhesion, so keep that in mind. Maybe, print them separate or with a raft or brim.

I have built supports into the model. They are not the best supports but way better then what my slicer produced. I use a pair of needle nose pliers to gingerly remove the supports and the cylinder ones are the trickiest. For the cylinders I would press with the pliers on the slits so they come off easier.

ProtoShort has an additional support under the center part of the body.

As far as the caps are concerned, they all should work but keep in mind that these are to hold the end bearing on and each set is for only 1 side of the spinner. So you will need 2 sets, one for each end bearing. The only exception are the not_good_caps which are thumb caps for the center bearing.

(Update 3/4/17)
{
I have add the ProtoFreakShort. It is basically a Freak with the short center body.
I have added better_center_bearing_thumb_cap.stl which is better than not_good_caps.stl, but be warned are really tall so I wouldn't recommend for the short models.
I updated all of the previous models with, hopefully, easier to remove cylinder supports.
}
I used Autodesk Fusion 360 to make the models.

title: Tesla Model 3 Powertrain (BLDC Motor)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As of 2:08 PM 21 March 2017 here the video of the motor is! https://youtu.be/r2rbYOiP4lQ
I will continue to work on improving the motion.

As of July 2017, I broke the motor shaft and cannot 3D print a new one until Late August...

SAFETY FIRST!!! KEEP COMPUTERS AWAY FROM PERMANENT MAGNETS AT ALL TIMES. IF ONE OF THESE MAGNETS COMES WITHIN APPROXIMATELY ONE FOOT OF YOUR COMPUTER, IT MAY JUMP OUT OF YOUR HAND AND COME INTO CONTACT WITH YOUR COMPUTER. CONTACT BETWEEN MAGNETS AND COMPUTERS WILL RESULT IN DESTRUCTION OF THE HARD DISK AND LOSS OF ALL DATA ON YOUR COMPUTER!! SERIOUSLY, THIS HAPPENED TO ME WHILE BUILDING THIS. I HAD TO BUY A NEW COMPUTER.

This is a DCBL Electric Motor. It sounds complicated because it is. These parts can be printed, but it took me about 30 hours of assembly and coding to get every last little detail right.

Carefully!

Read the other sections for assembly instructions. This is going to be me yelling at you about magnet safety again!

BE CAREFUL AROUND NEODYMIUM MAGNETS. THEY ARE DANGEROUS. THEY CAN DESTROY COMPUTER DISKS BY COMING WITHIN SIX INCHES. THEY COULD DESTROY A COMPUTER IN A PACEMAKER. IF TWO MAGNETS COME INTO CONTACT WITH EACH OTHER, YOU WILL PROBABLY NOT BE ABLE TO SEPARATE THEM WITHOUT SPECIAL TOOLS! BE CAREFUL! PLEASE!

BE CAREFUL!!!!!!!

What causes this motor to turn? All electric motors run function because of Electromagnetism. Electromagnetism is complicated. This could be built in pairs of two because it takes a long time to assemble. In this lesson, students will be able to learn about magnetism through the construction of a DC Brushless Electric Motor. Students will also learn about circuitry and Arduino C if they choose to follow the same design as I did.
Lesson This lesson will be in the PLTW style, with kids individually or in pairs working on developing this system. The instructions for assembly are in the "Assembly" section under Materials Needed.

Materials Needed -Neodymium Magnets (https://goo.gl/6ePA1g has the right dimensions)
-Enameled Copper Wire (28 AWG) (I used goo.gl/zphAXL)
-Thin Ferromagnetic Wire (Iron, Steel, Nickel) OR Iron filings
-3D Printer
-3D Printed parts
-Arduino Uno
-6 Transistors
-Arduino Shift Register
-Lots of wires
-Large Electronics Breadboard Assembly Following printing, the printed parts should be cleaned The motor "core" (The object with six inverted T-shaped things) will be the hardest part to build. Wrap ONE layer of the ferromagnetic wire around each of the six T-shaped things. Alternatively, you can fill the T's with iron filings. Then, leaving about a three-inch lead, begin wrapping the enameled copper wire around the T-shaped things individually. Each one will take 45-60 minutes to wrap, and is done when the "T" has essentially become a block of copper wire. Leave another 3-inch lead on the other end and cut the wire. Wrap all six of the T's separately. When you have finished winding the wire, build the Arduino circuit and connect everything exactly as I did in the image below. Download my code (goo.gl/sQCfD) to your Arduino circuit. What's happening? The Arduino is sending 5-volt pulses through each of the electromagnetic coils on the motor. This causes the coils to form a magnetic field. The magnetic field attracts the North pole of the Neodymium magnets on the shaft, and when the 5-volt pulse moves to the next electromagnet, the motor turns to follow it. This is not a very powerful motor because there is not much ferromagnetic substance on the inside of the electromagnets. Mostly this is just a fun toy for nerds; I calculated my torque to be (very approximately) half of a foot-pound of force. (less than 1/10 newton-meters). A few more hints and cautions to take So, in case you missed the rest of my warnings, I did literally destroy my hard drive on my computer with my magnets while making this. It was only a $150 repair, but I lost all of my data and settings. The magnets (sorry, I promise I don't try to annoy you all with magnet safety warnings) also broke my fingernail when I had one in my hand and the other jumped off of my workbench and crushed my finger. I found it helpful to tape my fingers while winding the wire, 28 gauge enameled copper wire will really cut into your skin. If the motor is not spinning and is just vibrating, that's probably because some of your electromagnets were wound the opposite direction. I just switched the wires around on mine until it started spinning instead of vibrating.

• Computing
  • Computer Science
  • Electromagnetism
  • electricity
  • Assembly
2 weeks
Preparation This would be a PLTW style lesson, and students would build this with school supplied materials (listed in the materials section).

Assessment Does it work? How close is it to working? I would recommend that any motion is classified as an 80-90%, and a spinning motion is 100% If the circuitry is built and seems sound, and it is not moving for unidentifiable reasons, I would give the students an 80%

There are few descriptions of DCBL motors on the internet, and I mostly used Google Images, as well as the previously listed tesla blog post.
I also reviewed the Wikipedia page on Brushless Electric Motors.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brushless_DC_electric_motor

What exactly is a DCBL (Also called a BLDC) motor?

A DCBL motor is similar to a Brushed Electric Motor, except it does not have as much heat loss due to the lack of Brushes. Brushes, in Brushed Electric Motors, change the direction of current thought the motor every 2π/3 radians (120 degrees). This is inefficient, as the brushes spark, releasing lots of heat, every 2π/3 radians. A DCBL motor removes brushes entirely, and instead has a permanent magnet axel usually containing 20+ permanent magnets of alternating polarity. Instead of having Brushes that switch the polarities, a control unit, changes the polarity of coils around the magnets.

Sorry. I don't think that description was very helpful. You can try reading the wikipedia article on DCBL motors here: (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brushless_DC_electric_motor)

What are DCBL motors used for?

Hybrid Electric Cars.
Basically nothing else.

Because of the unique structure of a DCBL motor, it allows for higher efficiency, something that virtually only matters in battery electric vehicles. Today, all HEV's (hybrid electric vehicles) (such as the Toyota Prius and Chevy Volt) use DCBL motors, while most BEV's (battery electric vehicles) (Tesla Model S, Tesla Model X, GM EV1, Chevy Bolt, Nissan Leaf), use/used Three Phase Induction motors. In a blog post, Tesla admitted that they are not certain which is better, Three Phase Induction or DCBL. They did say that DCBL motors are easier to make, and that's why I chose to make one.

Here is Tesla, Inc.'s article on Induction vs DCBL motors. (https://www.tesla.com/blog/induction-versus-dc-brushless-motors)

A replica of GM's EV1, the first major use of a Three Phase Induction motor. DCBL Motors were previously used in Hybrid-Electric Vehicles As ugly as priuses are, they car have a simple to build and program Brushless DC Electric Motor Cost of an equivalent motor

I did a quick search on Amazon for DCBL motors and found that a motor of equivalent size to the one I made would cost about $600.00. That one would probably be a bit more reliable, but I think it's way cooler to make your own thing.

For comparison, I was able to make this motor for less than $100.00.

comments.text: Nice project, but Honestly, it has NOTHING to do with Tesla. Every EV, actually, nearly every device has BLDC Motors today
comments.author: tobimai

comments.text: That's what I actually thought at first, but it turns out the EV1, the Chevy Volt/Bolt, the Nissan LEAF, and the Tesla Roadster 1, Model X and Model S all have Three Phase AC Induction motors. Tesla wrote a blog post about their choice of 3-phase induction motors when they were designing the original roadster, and I was surprised when I learned that the Model 3 would be using BLDCs.
comments.author: tobimai

comments.text: It seems you found very old, very outdated info, first hybrid car (toyota prius) was using 2 BLDC motors back in 1995, and toyota use them since now in all hybrids, only home made construction often don't use them now. 3 phase AC induction motors were used long long time ago when neodymium magnet price was insane so there was  no other option. Realy your thing has nothing specific to tesla and it looks like keyword search manipulation.
comments.author: kbpiper01

comments.text:
The prius has always had BLDC's. The Tesla M3 is the first fully electric car to have BLDC's. Neodymium magnet price is not the limiting factor, it is rather that they are a pain in the ass to manipulate. I know from experience. I killed my computer making this motor. As stated in one of Tesla's early blogposts, Tesla would use 3 Phase AC Induction Motors to reduce manufacturing costs, and every single fully electric production vehicle until now has used 3PACIM's. Although Toyota has always used BLDC's, Tesla, GM, and Nissan have always used 3PACIM's. Rimac Concept One, Neo EP 9, Formula E cars, Tesla M3, and the Tesla Semi are the only fully electric cars I have encountered that use BLDC's.
*This surprised me when I first found out. It seems like BLDC's are more simple and more powerful for their size, and while they are better in some aspects, they are more difficult to mass produce.
**Yes, I am slightly manipulating the tags, but if an improper tag leads to more people doing research and learning something surprising, I don't really care. I'm only getting about 50 more views per month since I changed the name, and I don't actually benefit from getting more views...

15%

Notes:

Shell thickness 1.2mm (eff 3x layers w/ 0.4mm nozzle)
Bottom/Top thickness 0.8mm
Print Speed 40mm/s
Perimeter on, 2x laps, min length 150mm
1.75mm PLA white filament from 3DFILLIES.COM
Initial layer thickness 0.3mm
100mm/s travel, 10mm/s infill. Sliced with Cura 15.04.3 and printed via SD card

Printing a Brim maybe necessary but will require additional cleanup

Ingrediants
  • Copy of Autodesk Mesh Mixer (or other favorite mesh editing tool that can planar cut)
  • Copy of the model
Step 1 - Fire up autodesk and load up the model Step 2 - Perform the first cut

After importing the model, select "edit" from the side bar, then select "Plane Cut"

Position the "cut" such that the top 90% is sliced

Ensure that the Cut Type is "Slice (keep both)"

Step 3 - Perform the same, but for the bottom 10%

Again ensure that you are perform a "Slice (keep both)" so to avoid loosing the other bits we already cut.

Step 4 - Seperate shells

Separate the shells so we can continue working on the part

Before After Step 5 - Select and Delete the inner piece

Thus leaving our two desired bits remaining

Step 6 - Now move, select and combine our two seperate pieces into a single piece

I tend to do a minor overlap to ensure combining works properly

FInished

Run an analysis to ensure that all is well and print your new part :)

title: "The Force" controlled RC Thunder Trax
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This project hacks an Air Hogs Thunder Trax RC vehicle by replacing the standard remote with an accelerometer enabled gauntlet. To control the vehicle, you simply move your hand in the direction you want it to go. Master Yoda would be proud.

This project was inspired by someone with a disability affecting one arm leaving them only in control of their right arm. This hack allows them to enjoy the fun of controlling an RC vehicle with just one arm.

The project was implemented with education in mind as well. All circuits are open and easily visible so that one can see all the components required to make it work.

All printing instructions, construction details, and program listing are provided in the attached Build Instructions PDF file. Additionally, we created a STEM educational handout to provide to students at science fairs, maker fairs, and STEM expos.

Enjoy!
DJ Hatfield
H5 Labs

title: 220 Quadcopter with ZMR (250?) arms - 5" props max

description.text:
• Update: 28th of May 2017
    • + New part added "Top Plate V2 - Corrected": I am finalizing this thingy by adding a new frame part I personally like and has managed to withstand severe crashes! There is an indication of the camera angle and will fit foxeer like cameras. With enough slots for cable and components management as well a slot for any additional component. The height of clearance is 24mm.
    • + New part added "Battery Holder V3": The model can be sliced with up-to 3 perimeters for additional strength and not intercepting one another
  • Update: 4th of March 2017
    • +Added "Basic building requirements" section
    • +Added "Other notes" section
  • Update: 5th of March 2017
    • +Added new camera mount v2: This utilizes bolts with wider head and also will keep the camera at approx. 50 degrees

This is my first attempt to create a quadcopter and use the 250-ZMR arms that were laying around and the carbon arms will make it more crash resistant. It is not a pure X-frame as the distance between arms, on the left and right side, is longer than the horizontal distance from the front and back arms, as an attempt to increase the overall agility for a more aggressive flying.

Basic building requirements:

  • 4x ZMR 250 arm, 3mm thick
  • 4x 35mm long standoffs
  • The frame will fit any standard sized (30mmx30mm) PDB and FC
  • Battery can either be mounted on top or at the bottom. The plate holder can be used as a component platform for making some extra space between the middle plate and the rest of the components for a battery strap to pass through
  • Battery holder will fit a 4s (1550mah) battery
  • Camera mount will fit a Foxeer 1177

Printing Settings recommendations:

  • Middle plate: This part will prove how crash resistant the frame is and it should be printed with at least 35% infill, 3 horizontal perimeters and 3 layers for both bottom and top.
  • Bottom plate: Like the middle plate above this also should be printed with similar settings so the frame to become more rigid.
  • Plate holder: This part does not need to be as rigid as the above ones. I primarily use it to create a small platform between the middle plate and the components so to make it easier for a battery strap to pass through.

Other Notes:

  • Regarding the tolerances, all holes will tightly fit 3mm bolts. For both the bottom and top plate, I use plastic washers, 8mm in diameter and 1mm of thickness
  • In the case of the battery is mounted at the bottom, there shouldn't be any bolts coming in direct contact with the battery for no reason.

Bear in mind that since this is a work in progress, any suggestions are very welcome.

Have fun and happy flying!

title: HICTOP Foot Extension for Printer Leveling

description.text:
This is a very simple object to help level HICTOP printers. It's designed to fit under the rubber feet, and the height of the base is customizable (through the "Open in Customizer" link above) to fit whatever extra height you need to level your printer.

If you're not sure how much extra space you need for leveling, I'd suggest downloading the pre-made STL file which has a 1mm base. It prints quickly, and you can then use it to calculate how much extra base height you need.

Edit 04-March-17: the OpenSCAD file was modified to fix rendering problems in Thingiverse's Customizer, as well as in the quick renderer in OpenSCAD.

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-17

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Keep in mind that your print layer height, as well as any differences in height for the first print layer, will have an effect on how accurate the height of your printed foot leveler will be.

If your measurements were slightly off, I'd suggest sticking a piece or two of paper into the cup to give the foot a little extra height. While these feet do print quickly, there's no point in wasting plastic. :-)

I stick vinyl pads to the bottom of these feet to give them some traction. Printing in a flexible material might do the same thing, but I have yet to try printing in flexible materials.

I have been having problems with my support structures so I designed this to see the effect it had on various shapes. It includes many features to test for supports, bridging, drooping and print quality in general including: a large chamfer from the build platform, a large fillet from the build platform, a large fillet from print surface, small rectangles, two through holes (5mm and 10mm), a long thin rectangle, an ellipse, two large rectangles, a large diamond on filleted edge and a large arrow to show print orientation.

Things you might want to look out for or change to test supports are listed below. Note: features mentioned here are in reference to Simplify3D.

-Distance between the supports and the print will affect print quality and how easy it is to remove the supports. You can change this by changing the number of separation layers above and below as well as changing the horizontal separation distance. Smaller distances/layers will result in better print quality above the support but will generally be harder to remove - be careful about reducing it too much as the supports can become part of the print.

-Density of the supports is important for many things. Increasing it will mean that the support print quality will be better as it will provide a more uniform base to print on, however will result in longer print times, more material used and make it harder to remove. Increasing the number of dense layers to around 2 on top of the support will enhance print quality massively, however you risk the chance of unable to remove it from the print if you have no vertical separation layers. Reducing density is not a great idea as print quality will suffer severely if you go too far.

-Strength of infill especially for smaller islands of support is important, otherwise features above them may fail. You can increase support strength without touching the density by adding support angle offsets of -45 and 45 degrees (credit: MakersMuse, thanks Angus).

-Support pillar resolution can sometimes have a massive effect on what gets support and what doesn't. Using a 4mm support pillar resolution means that smaller features may be neglected and fail without support. By reducing the resolution to 1mm (this is the minimum value), it's more likely that auto-generated supports will be placed where they need to be. Careful though, sometimes slicers can be weird and put supports where they aren't needed. Either manually remove them with the customise support tool or increase the pillar resolution.

-Whilst a heated chamber increases the chances of good layer adhesion and decreases warping due to fast cooling of ABS, it can have a detrimental affect on unsupported features. For example, I had trouble printing the 45 degree chamfer from the build platform (sagging) due to the heat in the chamber. I solved this by turning the fan to a maximum value of 50%. While this doesn't have an active cooling effect like you want for PLA in a "non-heated" chamber, it moves the hottest air under the extruder away from the print and allows the ABS to solidify a bit quicker.

Hope this helps :)

description.text:
Ho acquistato un paio di supporti per monitor da attaccare al poggiatesta ma i ganci si sono rotti dopo poco tempo. Inoltre la struttura era rumorosa e poco ferma.
Ho disegnato questo supporto su misura per il sedile della Opel Zarifa Tourer (anno 2012). La particolarità è che il poggiatesta scorre sulle barre: queste sono tutt'uno con il sedile.

author: drtaly

description.text:
We live in a brick house with double walls filled with isolation. There are holes in the wall to make sure moisture can get out. The disadvantage is that insects can come in and make hives. I have problems with wasps.
You can buy these items, they are called "bijenbekjes" in Holland. But i need more than 100 of then.

I designed this insect "filter" to prevent insect to get inside the walls, and still allow the air to flow freely. I printed it in two parts for two reasons:

  • The prnt orientation of the clamp. It is supposed to bend so the layers must be along the print
  • You do not see the clamp so i can use old filament with all colors.

I glue the two pieces together with hot glue.

The preview of the scad file looks bad, but if you download it is looks good, see screenshot.

The variable names and the comment is still Dutch, but all is configurable. I will try to translate it if I have the time.

Size of the item: l = 54 mm, w = 20 mm h = 32 mm
In openscad use l for length. It calculates the actual length depending on the with of the openings. use breedte for width and top for the height.

use a 4mm drill to widen the two holes in the clamp.

title: Train freight car for OS-Railway - fully 3D-printable railway system!

description.text:
OS-Railway is a complete railway kit designed from the ground up to be fully 3D-printable! Everything from track, switches, locomotives and cars and accessories are specially designed to be printable.

Note! this is the first version, I apologize in advance if not everything fits together perfect, I have printed and built one and it works so don't hesitate to ask in the comments if you have any questions!

Update 27/6/2017 Added a shorter version of the chassis on request, the short version is 195mm. The orientation of the holes in respect of the boogies are still the same, although other things like hopper car addon and other stuff made for the longer chassis will of course not work with this one.

Update 7/4/2017 I changed the coupling to a new simpler but more rigid version. It is a simpler coupler than the one made by gfrantz so if you want the most scale like, click on the link below.

Scale coupler Click on the following link for a scale like coupling mechanism made by gfranz: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2196463

Update! gfrantz has made some nice doors for the container, you can find them here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2159257
Container stand: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179125

This is the page for freight car, please see separate pages for tracks, locomotives and more.
Tracks: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2146361

This is the first version of the freight car. It is made to be a flexible chassi platform with several M2 holes distributed over the chassi in order for you to mount different structures on top. In the pictures I just placed a 20 foot ISO container on it for visual reference. I will make more fastening elements and other things for this car although I prioritize the track system now when this car is functional. Check this page now and then to see updates. I will not change the chassi so you will be able do download and mount upgrades later on if you print and assemble the chassi now.

What you need:

  • 8pcs ball bearings 6mm OD 3mm ID and 2,5mm W. (I will use these as standard).
  • 4pcs wheel shafts, 42mm lenght, 3mm thickness. I used carbon fiber rod
  • 8pcs M2x8-10 (between 8 and 10mm, not critical which) (absolut max 12mm)
  • 4pcs M3x10 hex (these keep the car holder in place in the middle of the bogie, therefore their heads cannot be too wide. The car holder needs to rotate freely so that the train car can cope with vertical radius for bridges, so don't set them tight.)
  • 2pcs M3x10-12 to attach the bogies to the chassi. I designed the chassi with room for a nut, but when I mounted the car I realized that the screw set so tight without so there is no need for the nut. Without nut you can use M3x10, if you want to use a nut, you need M3x12.
  • 2pcs M3x10 to attach couplers.
  • 2pcs M1,6x5-6 for the coupler assembly (if you only have longer ones, don't worry, they are easy to cut off.)

Notes on printing and assmbly

  • The chassi is made to be printed upside-down. That is why there is a chamfer angle to the side details to avoid the need for support. Note, there can be a bit trouble with the room for the bogie nuts, so if you intend to use such, you can enable support from build plate so that this space is printed nice and clean.

  • Ballbearings To mount the ballbearings in the bogie sides, a good way is to use a vice. It's a very tight fit and is supposed to be. You can trim the edges a bit so it's easier to guide the ball bearing right.

  • Orientation on print bed Take a look at the image showing all the parts on the build plate, NOTE! I do not recommend that you print all at once like this, I always print a couple of parts at a time to avoid loosing a whole batch if something goes wrong. This pictures is only intended to show you the orientation the parts should have on the build plate for best result.

  • Bogie sides require a tight fit to the hub, use a knife to trim the edges if it doesn't fit perfect. If you mount the sides and they don't fit perfect, your wheel shafts will not align and all wheels will not touch the track.

  • The included container is just a modified old CAD-file for reference, just to have something to put on the chassi. It doesn't print perfect and lack doors, but I include it anyway as it's in the pictures.

  • The coupler system has been designed after the Z70 locomotive was published. If you printed the first version, don't worry, the only thing you need is a 3mm hole on the underside on the back to attach a screw to mount the coupler arm. Place it center, roughly 4-5mm in (it's not critical a mm here or there doesn't matter). Only make sure that you don't drill all the way into your sevo if you have mounted one (I did...). The coupler has a 4mm hole but stil use a 3mm screw, this is intentional to give the coupler a bit of freedom of movement.

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% - 100%

Notes:

Note, chassi can be printed with less infill, I used 60%.

All other parts, print with 100% infill.
This was designed using Fusion 360. It's designed to be printable, so the print bed was used (with a slight margin) as reference for the car chassi length.

title: ATmega328p and ATtiny85 ISP programmer case + board tutorial

description.text:
Why this?

This is a case for my programmer breakout board I made because i got tired of using breadboards to program my chips. :) Nice weekend project.

Updates

2017.03.04:
Now with a button and a switch

2017.03.05:
Tutorial! scroll down

2017.03.06:
Additional tray (optional expansion) to store your chips, some nuts and bolts.
What a coincidence! ATmega328 fits really tight left to right, I repeat, I did NOT measure the chip before designing the tray! :D

Other projects

Tamaguino
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2120692
https://alojzjakob.github.io/Tamaguino/

Website traffic / Like monitor with NodeMcu
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2286288

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50

Did you recently get a skill to "shrinkify" your Arduino project?
If so, you probably wired your ATtiny or ATmega chip using breadboard and used your standard Arduino as ISP programmer to flash these chips. Now you can create your own chip programming breakout board, which also has a mini breadboard, so you can do some initial testing of your chips, i.e. does the chip work, does it run blink sketch etc.

Required skills For this project to succeed, only soldering skills and basic Arduino knowledge are required. Below is the circuit schematic. Note that you are not soldering chips, but sockets. I decided in my case that chip sockets should be oriented top to bottom (pin 1 goes top left).
Also note that on schematic additional 2 rows of female headers are not shown for simplicity. You will basically connect these to corresponding pins on each side of chip sockets.

Double sided prototype board 4x6cm This is the board we are going to solder components onto. Female headers You can cut these at any number of pins that are required 28-pin and 8-pin DIP sockets I used round hole female headers to solder to the board, and then sockets can sit on top of it, so both combined match the height of square female headers, which will be soldered alongside for extra pin access points A vertical sliding Switch This one is used to optionally disconnect pin 13 (ATmega) and pin 3 (ATtiny) from the LED on this board Push button Used to reset the chip, connects reset line to ground when pressed 2 LEDs One for power indication, one for pin13/pin3 Resistor(s) We need one resistor for the power indicator LED to limit the current through it.
I did not use the resistor for pin13/pin3 LED because chips have internal resistors. USB TinyISP programmer or similar In this project I used this programmer to connect to 6-pin header.
Pinout diagrams Below you can find pinout diagrams for ATmega328 and ATtiny85

description.text:
The fastest way to fasten/unfasten a lace-up shoe.

Inspired by Magnetic Shoelaces by adafruit.

You need 3 neodimium magnets of 12 mm in diameter and 5 mm in height for each piece (12 for the complete set). In the EU you can purchase at Supermagnete.

On each piece, insert the magnets with the same pole up and in the opposite with the same pole down. To facilitate the operation, mark the faces of the magnets with a marker.

Once the pieces are printed, insert the magnets into the holes and glue the lids with acetone or PVC cement (if it is ABS).

The 3-hole / 2-piece magnets has been obtained by cutting the original piece with Netfabb at 24 and 40 mm on the Y-axis, discarding the center and joining the ends. With this method you can make pieces of any number of holes (from 2).

Cierres magnéticos para zapatillas con cordones.

La forma más rápida de abrochar/desabrochar una zapatilla de cordones.

Inspirado en Magnetic Shoelaces by adafruit.

Se necesitan 3 imanes de neodimio de 12 mm de diámetro y 5 mm de alto para cada pieza (12 para el juego completo). En la UE se pueden adquirir en Supermagnete.

En cada pieza, insertar los imanes con el mismo polo hacia arriba y en la opuesta con el mismo polo hacia abajo. Para facilitar la operación, marcar las caras de los imanes con un rotulador.

Una vez impresas las piezas, insertar los imanes en los huecos y pegar las tapas con acetona o pegamento de PVC (si es ABS).

La pieza de 3 agujeros/2 imanes se ha obtenido cortando la pieza original con Netfabb a 24 y 40 mm en el eje Y, desechando la central y uniendo los extremos. Con este método se pueden hacer piezas de cualquier número de agujeros a partir de 2.

comments.text: Hello. I uploaded an archive  (Less weight STL files.zip) with lighter STL files, lowering the quality a bit.

comments.text: Thanks mate. It worked as a charm.
comments.author: Dagongar

comments.text: have you found this to be stronger than using smaller magnets orientated with the circular face toward the opposing piece as in other designs. I like that the magnets are well retained here, but the cost for this size of magnet-  is it justified by a significant improvement in function?
comments.author: Abbadon2001

comments.text: I have calculated different options with the magnets of Supermagnete and this configuration is the one that has greater force of adhesion. The strength of small magnets is not proportional to their size, but is even smaller. More smaller magnets, even face to face, do not add as much force as this configuration. To have greater strength it would be necessary to use larger magnets or to place the 12 mm magnets vertically, face to face. I've used these closures for months to walk without problems, though I do not trust them to run.

description.text:
I designed this ratchet screwdriver to be adaptable for all 6-Kant 1/4 of inch bits.
The bit rotation is locked while unscrewing and for screwing the spring provides a torque control.
The maximum torque depends on the spring stiffness and on the length of the spacer. To adjust the maximum torque for screwing I also included a M5 nut in the back of the handle that allows to increase the torque screwing on the back of the screwdriver a M5 bolt (This part is optional).
The ratchet is a single piece that have to be printed twice: one for the head of the screwdriver (have to be inserted in it) and one moving with the spring.

I used a spring of 6.5x18mm, if you have a spring of a different lenght just modify the spacer length on CAD file.

0.2 and 0.1 for ratchet

30%

I used PLA, but probably it is better to use ABS for ratchet part in order to have a better strength

description.text:
This is a tips holder for Hakko T12 (and clones) tips.
I designed this to be fixed (double sided tape) on top of the case designed by "vtoryh" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1220238).
You can change the number of supported tips in the OpenSCAD source ("BaseTipNum" parameter).

Take care not to lift the tips too high while extracting them as it's possible to break their base plastic cap (even if it's not easy to do).
Note that as the tips are grabbed over their label, it can be damaged by the holder fingers...

author: daniela_bravo

description.text:
This design replaces the existing Y-belt bearing holder on the Mendel90. This is a two-piece design that allows for tensioning of the Y-belt similar to how the X-belt is tensioned.  
The existing bearings, washers, and securing pieces are used with this new design. However, instead of an M4 screw securing the tensioner to the Dibond base, the design simply 'hugs' around the edge of the Dibond.  
A screw is used between the tensioner base and sliding portion to allow for tightening or loosening the Y-belt.  
I'm currently using one of the clip arms from the bulldog clips between the tensioner base and slider to set a certain distance between the two so that I can easily retension the belt back to where I had it.

description.text:
03/19/2017 UPDATE !

Simple 3-parts tape dispenser, properly sized (for standard tape roll - Ø 25mm).
Just print the adaptator (4th part) to adapt your dispenser for other tape rolls (Ø 35-37mm) !
Really easy to print, no any supports needed, only a raft, following the quality of your 3D printer !
You can choose to print all part at the same time or not, (in this case please download the .zip archive called "V_3.0_Detached").
Printed in about 2 or 3 hours (depending of your settings).

3 versions :

  • V_3.0_Last version, design improved, adjustements corrected.
  • V_2.1_Old version.
  • V_2.0_Old version, without blade (only 2 parts to print ; you'll have to add your own steel blade, if you have it)

Mass (PLA) : ~ 30 g

Feel free to comment, like, and share this model if you like it to help me !
Don't forget to SHARE YOUR MAKING ! (That's very important for me).

At your service ;)
Jetstorm.

PS : Les français vous pouvez commenter en français je pourrai vous répondre ! ;D

Printer:

CTC (mk8)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

0.25 mm layer height

10%

comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: Thank you really glad it's useful. I am thinking about making a larger version that has space for the whole of the character card content so can just use this. (Not the actual character card but a smaller reworking of it). What do you think? Would need one for each character with custom art work stuck on or a slot for a reduced size card.
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text:
I was thinking some sort of dashboard would be useful, but I'd personally prefer something more generic (so I don't have to print 17 of them!) With this xp/hp dial, the card is indeed unnecessary, but I would like to see some smaller printed place for a discard and lost pile, as well as some slots for items and active cards. Perhaps something a bit like: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1633509
It's a difficult problem since a character can potentially have quite a lot of items though. As it stands, I'm quite happy with the replacement hp/xp trackers. The rest can still fit in the character boxes, so it's not that much extra to store. Either way, I'm quite happy with this design. However, I printed Bill Paterno's files on full sheet labels with an inkjet printer. I use gluesticks for adhesion on a glass bed on my printer. After printing, I rinsed the excess glue off the bottom of the printed parts, then dried them off. I stuck the printed images on, then found out about 30 minutes later that there must have been some excess water left inside the print. It has caused a bit of water damage to the printed image, but the dial portion is still legible. This brings up the point of somehow sealing the parts once the image is applied. I notice yours is shiny in the picture. Did you laminate it first? I was thinking about using some spray sealant to help protect the next few I make. I'll give it a shot and let you know.
Oh, by the way, one other thing I feel would add a lot is some 3d overlay prints. I've printed off and painted some nifty loot markers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:328755), but I've been hunting for some traps and columns and such. If you're looking for more things to model, that would be quite welcome. Cheers!
comments.author: Flounder1664

comments.text: It's a friends game and didn't realise there were 17 characters! Yes I have to agree I'm not making one for each. I just printed on normal paper covered with wide clear tape and used glue stick to stick the image down. I did think about making a slight recess for the image..
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: Yeah, I've found barrels and crates and some other furniture, but we really need something for the poisonous gas, bear traps, spike traps, lava and a few others. I couldn't believe there weren't any either. I'm super amateur at modelling, so I'll leave the design work to you though! If you're willing, that is. If not, I'm super grateful for the dials anyhow.

author: Flounder1664

title: Aldi Workzone ( Einhell) 18v Battery Break out Adapter

description.text:
This is a Battery Breakout Adapter for the Range of Aldi Workzone ( Einhell) 18/20V power tools .
It connects directly to the power tools , as the normal battery would. It has a built in Spring latch to lock it in place . It can then be adapted to a range of batteries from other brands of power tools .It has been specifically designed to screw directly on to the really neat "Makita Battery Mount" designed & posted by Gary Platek , which can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:352094
This allows it to connect directly to the Range of Makita 18V Lithium-Ion battery packs .

Small "L" shaped electrical terminals need to be cut from thin guage sheet metal .They fit neatly through the printed slots in the main body ,& can be securly screwed into place in the printed mounting holes , with self tapping screws .Bend them as shown it the photo, to give them a spring action to the electrical contact . Terminal lugs are used for power connection . If you are connecting to the "Makita Battery Mount" use our " Makita 18V battery Terminal" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2156290 & the connections will line up so that compression springs can be used make the electrical connection with no need for wiring ,

Note : The "Makita Battery Mount appears to have been designed in Imperial Dimensions, & may appear in Cura extremley small. Just up scale it by a factor or 25.4 on all axis to correct the size .

author: Fran008

description.text:
This is the set of three cubes each connected by faces or edges. With this set you can rather easily make a 3x3x3 cube, but it's a little bit harder to solve this than to solve the SOMA cube.
To allow for the connections between edges the edges are chamferinged.
The size of the grid structure is 15mm and the faces have an inset of 0.25mm.

I wrote a program to do the task. First for each cube a polyeder with six squares, twelve rectangles (for the edges) and eight triagles for the corners was calculated. If faces or edges meet a little box was inserted and hidden rectangles were removed.
For three pieces the slicer added support structures.

title: Mk8 extruder mod

description.text:
Those Aluminium Mk8 Extruders have all that filament guiding part missing , well not all but the cheaper ones for sure, and it has been a pain to to change filament without that guiding part ! All you need to complete this is some small piece of PTFE (teflon) tubing to fit insite upper guide hole
So here it is .. hope it can be helpful as much it helped me, enjoy!

comments.author: defcone

comments.text:
MK8 as supplied has the hotend heatsink where you part goes, so it won't work.
Easier and better to just extend the PTFE tube or depending on the hot end, the 6mm steel tube and bevel it.Did it on my MK8 then in my own designed extruder/hotend. Anyway, I already wrote that many time for the same designs.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: It works pretty fine on my printers and those of my friends wich i did give this design months  ago, decided to publish it only now cause i got asked a lot how i manage to print flexibles so flawlessly. By the way the majority of these Aluminium kits come without the cooling fin's wich is not needed anyway, just check the pictures and you will see how it goes mounted together, nothing simpler as that, no need to extend and bevel throat.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I am speaking about the best and simplest way to do it. Took me 5 min to do on my MK8.
Your choice to make it more complicated and limited than it should be.
Note there is plenty of similar 3D printed guides published here, at least yours use a PTFE tube which is fine.
comments.author: PaoloRob

comments.text:
The best and simplest way for a 3D printer owner is without any doubt to simply print it ! Your suggestion is totally unpractical and for most users it will imply to buy a longer throat , to have and use tools to shape that metal part and not every 3D printer user has this at hands. you say it took you 5 min to do it , i say it's even doable in less as long you have the parts handy wich again regular 3D Printer Users have not. So there is nothing easier and simpler than press that print button and let the magic happen, once it's done just take a little piece of ptfe tubing, wich most printer come with some spares and sape it to match with a sharp knife, wich again is available in every household.
I did guess my self that there would surely have been some similar designs and i did not even bother to search for it, had this solution used since quite a few months now and shared the file among friends until i got asked to simply publish it, so that's how it got here.

author: PaoloRob

description.text:
These are frame spacers for the simplex type beehive. You can use them for broodboxes and honey supers. For the broodboxes, I think the bottom spacers are required since the frames are much longer. For the honey supers you only need the top spacers. Commercial spacers are basically a strip of metal you cut to length, but they lack the capability to position the frames in the middle of the box and distribute the bee space equally between sides.
Each spacer can hold 3 frames, so for the 11 frame simplex, you must cut a spacer (or you could ask me to add a 2 frame spacer). I used 3,0x20mm wood screws to attach the spacers in the boxes. Be aware that the dimensions of your boxes play a role in a good fit!
I don't have a lot of experience with bees yet, but I hope this little project will turn out ok. I hope the bees don't have an adverse reaction to PLA...

Printer:

Delta 3D

Rafts:

No

No

0.3

40

Notes:

I used plain PLA for this project and printed a little hotter than usual (200°C).
These spacers will be outside in the beehives, but will not have to endure the sun's radiation since they are inside the boxes.

The domsliced pentominoes are pentominoes with half of two neighboring squares cut away.
The pieces were suggested by Roel Huisman in the last century. For hand solvers it should be possible to produce 5-fold replicas of the pieces. The shown 6-fold replica was produced
by program. All replicas are possible. Interesting for solid pieces are the 4x4x9 and 6x6x4 boxes, because some pieces must be orthogonal to the other ones.

SVG-files for the perimeters were used to triangulate the bottom face and to get the corners
of the orthogonal faces. To get no problems with the sliced U-pentominoes and the sharp corners of the polygon the sides were shifted with an inset of 0.2mm. The size of the original squares is 15mm.

title: Alpha Piezo Hotend Z-Probe Mini Groovemount/Titan 20mm piezo

description.text:
Update 14-05-2017 This unit is now in release candidate and is available here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2319993
Also available to buy ready made at http://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk/shop

Update 16-7-17 latest thinking in terms of firmware setup can be read here http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,767998,page=9

Update 07-03-2017 Made a version for titan (or generic groovemount) where the top piece is two parts (instead of 3). Should be quite tight in the groovemount. Print it 100% infilled with moderate-high nozzle temperature for good layer adhesion. I have kept the 3 part top available in case you need it.

Update 05-03-17 - changed the length of the groove mount piece for titan so it should be snug against the base of the titan when fitted. Don't file/adjust the groove mount flange after printing its better if its a tight fit.

Update 05-03-17 - changed titan mount system (again), now the top plate of the sensor assembly is printed in two parts and then bonded back together at assembly, this enable the sensor surface and the surface for the groove mount adaptor to be smooth and free from support material.

Description

So not going to put a lot of detail here you can get the majority of the info on these devices from

http://reprap.org/wiki/Piezo-electric_sensors
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2069480

This is a miniature version piezo z-probe module using 20mm piezo. I have not enough time or a suitable machine to fully test it, but I have done some work on basic feasibility and it will trigger when connected to a piezo sensor signal conditioning board which you can make as per the circuit diagram in the wiki page above or by contacting Moriquendi on reprap forum who can sell one to you for a very modest amount, please be patient as he makes them in batches at home.

Assembly: important - drill out the 4x screw holes in the clamp/lower part to 3.2mm approx so that the screws do NOT bind or stick, the lower part needs to be able to "slide" on these screws (it's only 0.1mm). I used countersunk screws which can be screwed into (threaded) the top part to keep them fixed and steady, then m3 nuts or locknuts below the clamp/lower part. Do them up just beyond hand tight and evenly.

This unit could be integrated into a carriage, the titan version print it as orientated and then bond (acetone/superglue) the e3d groove mount piece into the top plate. This is necessary as the recess for the piezo needs to print well and should be upwards. Youll need a little support for the groove mount, this has to have a square collar to work so no easy support free orientation is possible.

If you make and test one please feedback to me via thingiverse any issues.

New drafts/revisions will appear here as/when.

title: Box Mod bottom feeder mechanical with push button lock (v3  p&p;)

description.text:
This is an evolution of this one > http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1758376
The idea was: no solder, all plug & play.
U need only sold a small copper/silver/brass to negative drip cap ring: all the rest is plug & play.

File explanation:

  • body_drip_cap_hole_10_mm: body with drip cap hole 10 mm (fat daddy)
  • body_drip_cap_hole_12_mm: body with drip cap hole 12 mm (mav)
  • bottle_spacer: the spacer for soft round bottle
  • fat_daddy_pin_locker: if u use fat daddy v5, u need this to block the pin contact
  • front_panel the front panel
  • push_button_body: body of push button with lock
  • push_button_top: the lock of push button.

To complete u need:

  • a drip cap;
  • some magnets 3x1 mm;
  • a brass/silver/copper strip: i used these http://fave.co/2cri1DS
  • keystone 5209: http://fave.co/2lI0utx or http://fave.co/2bsgxvX
  • a bottle

If u need a photo-tutorial u can follow this one > http://www.esigblog.com/box-mod-bottom-feeder-mini-meccanica-foto-tutorial/

Suggested print setting: 150 micron (0.15 mm).

This part replaces the bracket that holds the z-limit sensor on the Folgertech FT-5. It would probably work on other 3D printers that use a similar setup. The tolerances on the sliding parts are pretty tight and you will probably have to sand them to get them to move freely.

There are two different sensor holders depending on which side of the printer you put them on. I would recommend checking out Dustin's two sensor mod which uses a seperate z-limit switch for each FT-5 Z motor. Here is the link to his mod page. http://dustincorbin.weebly.com/blog/folger-tech-ft-5-dual-z-stepperendstops-mod

I used 3M automotive trim tape to attach mine because I already had my printer enclosed and screwing it in was going to be a pain, but I would recommend using some small wood screws and screwing it into the melamine.

The idea is that you can make tiny adjustments in your z-limit height by turning the knob making it easier to set the exact height for a good first layer.

If it works for you, leave me a tip for enough to buy a cup of coffee so I can keep making stuff.

If you have any ideas for improvement, let me know.

This is a simple dice, printed on a corner to make a nice even surface on all faces, but with a spherical cavity in them.  
If you put a spherical magnet in the cavity during printing you end up with some special dice - magnetic but not biased.  
This actually works quite well with a ball bearing rather than a magnet, making dice that don't roll too far, and have a nice rattle.

Prints with no extra support on makerbot, the support ring on base snaps off.  
Drop a small spherical magnet in at about 75% print. Suggest using a second magnet underneith to hold in place while finishing printing.

description.text:
Here is a simple yet effective kitchen paper holder.
Designed by me in OpenSCAD.
The design can be printed without supports in any material and color of your choice.

The bar in this example is made of a simple 15mm tube, but basically any diameter tube can be used.
Standard kitchen paper is 23cm wide. I have cut the tube at 30 cm to leave some extra space.
Since kitchen paper is not heavy, a single screw is sufficient to keep the holder attached to your wall. However, to avoid twitching, I have added a piece of double-sided tape to prevent this. This is not really necessary though.

Please do not use screws with conical heads, only flat-headed screws should be used.

Printer:

Mankati Fullscale XT/XT-Plus

No

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

25%-40%

Notes:

There is no need for supports in this model.
It can basically be printed on any 3D printer.

Just make sure you use enough infill to make the model sturdy enough.

This a custom mount for the ZeePro Zim to accommodate two modified e3d V6 hot ends without having to modify the pre-installed X-Y axis carriage. The only suggestion concerning print settings is that as out of the box the Zim is primarily a PLA machine, you should print the fan shroud in ABS. ABS has a higher melting point than PLA, and is a tiny bit more flexible. This is not a compete project. As seen in the assembly views, there is a print fan duct. I'll update the project with a fan duct as soon as I design a better one.

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Power supply cover w\LCD power meter

title: Power supply cover w\LCD power meter remix

description.text:
I really liked the design of this power supply cover, but I didn't have the power socket/switch assembly used in the original design. I re-fabricated this to hold a power socket that I pulled from an old computer power supply, and a rocker switch that I pulled out of the parts bin. I just used OpenSCAD to fill in the area where the original socket/switch hole was and create new ones.

I printed this with a pretty thin wall with about 20% infill and when I put the rear screw into the power socket it cracked the plastic slightly, so you may want to think about printing it with thicker walls and a higher fill density. Overall though it turned out good. Just need to get me an M3x45 screw for the front mounting hole.

More about me

For more information about me and other projects and things by me, take a look at my websirte at https://dan.bemowski.info/

title: [UPDATED March 6] Redesigned E3D V6 mount for Anet A8

description.text:
This is a work in progress so more parts will be added when time passes. I am redesigning the mounting solution for the Anet A8 so that the E3D assembly can be as close to the moving axis as possible. With this way of mounting it you will get less strain on the X-axis rods and the weight is nog as far out of the center of the axis thus meaning less twisting of those rods. Keep checking in for updates and please leave comments with suggestions or tips.

I am also trying to get it as compact as possible.

I will design it for the entire community so I need your feedback!

Thank you in advance!

Anet A8

Two different models available:

"Replace Tab"
Should be used if the original tab / tab pieces have been lost.

"Over Top Tab"
Should be used if the original broken tab pieces are available to be glued inside this printed tab. Can also be glued over an unbroken tab to strengthen it.

There is one tab per pollen filter cover.
'Left' or 'Right' describes the tab on each single pollen filter cover from driver seat looking forwards.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Used skirt/brim rather than raft.
Used ABS with ABS/Acetone solution as bed glue.

Finish

I used normal two part plastic epoxy from local store.
If using "Replace Tab" you will have to remove (sand/grind) the jagged edges of what remains before gluing printed piece on.
If using "Over Top Tab" you should just be able to assemble like jigsaw puzzle and glue in place.
I would trial fit before gluing.
Once fitted and the glue had dried, I drilled through and made the original holes slightly larger (approx 8mm dia) because I believe this to be part of the original failure mode = the pollen filter threads grab on the undersized hole creating a bending moment.

Tabs glued in place.

title: My modifications to Peter Sripol's Hover craft

description.text: Building upon Peter Sripol's amazing Hovercraft design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2108890) I added a few things. Some for esthetics and others for practicality. I designed a locking system for the cockpit requiring only one bolt that fastens into a nylon lock nut. I made a slide lock for the rear of the cockpit so it would be anchored as well. Underneath I made blocks to tie the front and mid hull sections together then added supports on the sides in the curved part of the hull for increased support for both the front-mid sections and mid-rear sections. These particular supports are approximately just over 2mm thick but add a great deal of strength while not adding much weight. Some trim may be needed with these parts but if anyone uses them I hope they like them. Added a 10mm taller cockpit with the holes on top removed for a cleaner look.

comments.text:
This is what I've done so far:
-Printed all the parts.
-Temporary glued them together.
-I used fiberglass putty on the outside to hide all the ugliness from the assembly and make it hold a lot better.
-Drilled holes to make room for screws and ventilation.
-Clothed the interior with fiberglass weave to prevent cracks and further reinforce it.
-I used wallpaper weave to create further textures where the metal paint is going.
-Then I used a lot of filler/spray putty to further fix the surface.
A lot of sandpaper has been used...

Español

El archivo storage.scad aporta un módulo llamado boxStorage que permite crear cajas o bandejas que pueden ser usadas para almacenar cosas de manera ordenada e introducidas luego en recipientes plásticos, tuppers, cajas de altoids, etc.

Además de los parámetros básicos como alto, ancho y largo, se pueden especificar otros parámetros adicionales que permiten modificar el resultado final, tal como se aprecia en las imágenes.

Sus principales funcionalidades son permitir que las filas o columnas sean asimétricas y poder usarse bordes redondeados de manera selectiva.

Para poder tener las filas y/o columnas asimétricas se debe especificar un array con los porcentajes que ocuparán cada fila/columna. La suma de estos valores debe ser igual a 1.

English

The file storage.scad provides a module called boxStorage that allows you to create boxes or trays that can be used to store things in an orderly way and then inserted into plastic containers, tuppers, boxes, altoids, etc.

Besides to the basic parameters such as height, width and length, you can specify additional parameters that can modify the final result, as seen in the images.

Its main functionalities are to allow the rows or columns to be asymmetric and selectively rounded edges.

In order to have asymmetric rows and / or columns, an array must be specified with the percentages that will occupy each row / column. The sum of these values must be equal to 1.

Uso / Usage

use </path/to/storage.scad>

boxStorage(width = 50, height = 50, length = 10, thickness = 2.4, radius = 2, rows = 2, cols = 3);

Enlace / Link

https://gitlab.com/joaquinfq/openscad/blob/master/Modules/Box/storage.scad
OpenSCAD
it is possible more small print but you have to use a resolution of 0.1...see photos
